questions.explanation: Affirmative Agreement ‡¶∏‡¶æ‡¶ß‡¶æ‡¶∞‡¶£‡¶§ ‡¶¶‡ßÅ‡¶á ‡¶≠‡¶æ‡¶¨‡ßá ‡¶∏‡¶Æ‡ßç‡¶≠‡¶¨, ‡¶®‡¶ø‡¶ö‡ßá Structure ‡¶¶‡ßá‡¶Ø‡¶º‡¶æ ‡¶π‡¶≤: Affirmative Statement + and + (1) Subject + (1I) So + { Verb Auxliary verb Do, Does, Did } + (II) Subject \begin{array}{l}\text { Affirmative } \\ \text { Statement }+ \text { and }+\begin{array}{l}\text { (1) Subject }+ \\ \text { (1I) So }\end{array}+\left\{\begin{array}{l}\text { Verb } \\ \text { Auxliary verb } \\ \text { Do, Does, Did }\end{array}\right\}+\text { (II) Subject }\end{array} Affirmative Statement + and + (1) Subject + (1I) So ‚Äã + ‚é© ‚é® ‚éß ‚Äã Verb Auxliary verb Do, Does, Did ‚Äã ‚é≠ ‚é¨ ‚é´ ‚Äã + (II) Subject ‚Äã ‡¶§‡¶¨‡ßá ‡¶è‡¶ï‡ßç‡¶∑‡ßá‡¶§‡ßç‡¶∞‡ßá main clause ‡¶è ‡¶Ø‡ßá verb ‡¶¨‡¶∏‡¶¨‡ßá ‡¶¶‡ßç‡¶¨‡¶ø‡¶§‡ßÄ‡¶Ø‡¶º Clause ‡¶ì ‡¶è‡¶ï‡¶á tense-‡¶è ‡¶π‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶π‡¶¨‡ßá‡•§ Person ‡¶Ö‡¶®‡ßÅ‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º‡ßÄ verb ‡¶≠‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßç‡¶® ‡¶π‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶∞‡ßá ‡¶ï‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßç‡¶§‡ßÅ Tense ‡¶†‡¶ø‡¶ï ‡¶•‡¶æ‡¶ï‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶π‡¶¨‡ßá‡•§ Exam: I am happy and you are too I am happy and so are you Exam: She will wear a costume to the party and we will too She will wear a costume to the party and so will we Exam: karim goes to the school, and Rahim does too karim goes to the school, and so does Rahim ‡¶Ü‡¶∞ Negative agreement ‡¶ì ‡¶¶‡ßÅ‡¶á‡¶≠‡¶æ‡¶¨‡ßá ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ ‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º‡•§ Negative Statement + \begin{array}{l}\text { Negative } \\ \text { Statement }\end{array}+ Negative Statement ‚Äã + And + { Subject+Negative Auxiliary/be + either Neither + positive auxiliary/be + subject } +\left\{\begin{array}{l}\text { Subject+Negative Auxiliary/be }+ \text { either } \\ \text { Neither }+ \text { positive auxiliary/be }+ \text { subject }\end{array}\right\} + { Subject+Negative Auxiliary/be + either Neither + positive auxiliary/be + subject ‚Äã } Exam: Karim hasn'tseen the movie yet, and I haven't either Karim hasn't seen the movie yet, and neither have I.

questions.question: The film ____by the time we get to the cinema.
questions.explanation: 1. Future perfect tense: The future perfect tense is used to describe an action that will be completed before a specific point in the future. 2. Rule for future perfect tense: It is formed using the future tense of the auxiliary verb "will" or "shall," the word "have," and the past participle of the main verb. 3. Correct sentence analysis: - "The film" is the subject of the sentence. - "will already have started" is the future perfect verb phrase. - "will" is the future tense auxiliary verb. - "already" indicates that the action will be completed before a certain time. - "have" is the auxiliary verb indicating completion. - "started" is the past participle of the main verb "start." 4. Incorrect options: - "will already start": This option lacks the completion aspect provided by the future perfect tense. - "will already be started": While grammatically correct, it doesn't express the perfect aspect of completion that "will already have started" does. So, the rule involves using the future perfect tense to express actions that will be completed before a specified point in the future.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: ‡¶ñ) disastrous Sentence ‡¶ü‡¶æ ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßã: "Global warming may have a _____ effect on life." ‡¶è‡¶á sentence-‡¶è gap ‡¶ü‡¶æ fill ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶π‡¶¨‡ßá ‡¶è‡¶Æ‡¶® ‡¶è‡¶ï‡¶ü‡¶ø adjective ‡¶¶‡¶ø‡ßü‡ßá ‡¶Ø‡¶æ negative effect ‡¶¨‡ßÅ‡¶ù‡¶æ‡ßü‡•§ "Disastrous" ‡¶∏‡¶†‡¶ø‡¶ï, ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶∞‡¶£ ‡¶è‡¶∞ ‡¶Æ‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßá ‡¶π‡¶≤‡ßã ‡¶¨‡¶ø‡¶™‡¶∞‡ßç‡¶Ø‡¶Ø‡¶º‡¶ï‡¶∞ , ‡¶Ø‡¶æ global warming-‡¶è‡¶∞ negative effect ‡¶¨‡ßÅ‡¶ù‡¶æ‡ßü‡•§ "Global" , "industrial" , ‡¶è‡¶¨‡¶Ç "pollutant" ‡¶≠‡ßÅ‡¶≤, ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶∞‡¶£ ‡¶è‡¶ó‡ßÅ‡¶≤‡ßã negative effect ‡¶¨‡ßÅ‡¶ù‡¶æ‡ßü ‡¶®‡¶æ‡•§ ‡¶§‡¶æ‡¶á, correct sentence ‡¶ü‡¶æ ‡¶π‡¶¨‡ßá: "Global warming may have a disastrous effect on life." (‡¶ó‡ßç‡¶≤‡ßã‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶≤ ‡¶ì‡¶Ø‡¶º‡¶æ‡¶∞‡ßç‡¶Æ‡¶ø‡¶Ç ‡¶ú‡ßÄ‡¶¨‡¶®‡ßá‡¶∞ ‡¶â‡¶™‡¶∞ ‡¶è‡¶ï‡¶ü‡¶ø ‡¶¨‡¶ø‡¶™‡¶∞‡ßç‡¶Ø‡¶Ø‡¶º‡¶ï‡¶∞ ‡¶™‡ßç‡¶∞‡¶≠‡¶æ‡¶¨ ‡¶´‡ßá‡¶≤‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶∞‡ßá‡•§) So, the correct answer is option ‡¶ñ‡•§

questions.question: He gave______

options.label: ‡¶ï
options.text: to the class a tough assignment

options.label: ‡¶ó
options.text: a tough assignment for the class

options.label: ‡¶ò
options.text: an tough assignment very tough to the class

questions.option_a: to the class a tough assignment
questions.option_c: a tough assignment for the class
questions.option_d: an tough assignment very tough to the class
questions.explanation: The correct answer is B. 'He gave the class a tough assignment.' This sentence is grammatically correct and conveys the intended meaning. The preposition 'to' is not necessary in this sentence. 'Gave' is followed by the direct object 'the class' and the indirect object 'a tough assignment.'
